>> Thank you very much,

34.34.text:
Hello, thank you all for

40.42.text:
for inviting me to

43.76.text:
Today I am going to talk
about material of the digital.

47.62.text:
And in particular have
some Slade artists

51.00.text:
over the last decade or so
so we're going to going back

56.64.text:
I have been translating all

60.44.text:
for gallery and other
physical or kind

65.34.text:
So just to give a
briefest of backgrounds,

69.03.text:
I'm currently the
Director of the Slade

73.68.text: which some of you may recognize.

75.74.text:
I was a student there
in the 1980s.

78.04.text:
And it was while I was a student
in the '80s I sort of stumbled

81.74.text:
across computers and
began exploring the use

85.04.text:
of technologies for
making art work.

88.75.text:
In 1995 I returned to the
Slade [inaudible] and that's

95.55.text:
for Electronic Media was set
up, also known as SCEFMA.

99.99.text:
And at the time SCEFMA
was really quite unique

104.02.text:
in encouraging the use
and the exploration of new

107.79.text:
and emerging technologies
as integral and embedded

110.91.text:
within a wider fine
arts studio practice.

113.51.text:
And it began very much
with an advocacy role.

116.99.text:
A lot of arts weren't even aware
of the use of the technologies.

119.99.text:
A lot of people with technology
maybe didn't see what was going

124.49.text:
And over the years that's
become less relevant

130.85.text:
And it's evolved into a research
group bringing together artists,

135.17.text:
students and researchers from
across the Slade and beyond here

139.15.text:
in some way exploring or
exploiting emerging technologies

146.34.text:
So for those of you that haven't
had the pleasure of going

149.00.text:
to the basement of the Slade,
a couple of pictures there.

151.82.text:
One of the most common
current threads that this group

157.17.text:
on the time particularly
engaged with is an exploration

160.64.text:
of the material of the digital,
the subject of this talk.

163.56.text:
And I'm really looking
to it from a whole range

165.65.text:
of different critical cultural
and quite tangible perspective.

170.30.text:
And what I plan to do in this

199.85.text:

204.07.text:

208.40.text:
And I'm going to start
with a work of mine

211.19.text:
and from the late 1990s and it's

214.86.text:
And it's a work that was
intended as an experiment.

219.90.text:
to bring together two very
different forms of public space,

223.25.text:

226.67.text:

people on the internet

with each other via camera,

235.36.text:
and then projected

240.77.text: by looking at the Web browser.

241.98.text:
There are probably people here
that never even saw Netscape.

245.88.text:
So it was installed in a
number of different locations

249.45.text:
and countries over
a four year period.

251.68.text:
And this is from its first
incarnation in Brighton.

255.58.text:
So on the street passersby
encountered an animated mouth

hidden loud speakers

by the internet users
who were trying to strike

which documented and

280.30.text:
by streaming media

288.76.text:
